SEG.ORIGINAL_TEXT: Best Charity to contribute to Nepal
Anyone who knows where your hard earned donations would go the furthest please post
Anyone who knows where your hard earned donations would go the furthest please post
Ultimately, there is no standard reporting on a 'cost of fundraising' ratio - therefore you cannot easily compare charities on a like-for-like basis.

The amount of cash that gets through to the cause depends not only on the charity you're dealing with, but also on the channel you use and the type of appeal. Charities have to spend money to raise money, but the costs differ depending on the method they use. Charities often use several different ways to raise funds.

It really comes down to which causes matter to you most, and which organisations you think will be the most effective. If you have the time and inclination, do your own calculations. You'll need to flick to the end of annual reports for the figures. Compare fundraising revenue with fundraising costs and read the notes to financial statements to see how ratios are calculated.
Your profile says NZ, so I'd encourage you to stick with one of these:
You might especially be interested in this one:
Here are two suggested by ex American Peace Corps volunteers from Nepal....I have cut and pasted....

Friends of Nepal, Los Angeles has taken initiative to set up an emergency relief fund for the disaster recovery and relief efforts of the recent 7.8 magnitude earthquake that struck Nepal at noon on April 25, 2015. The fund is being collected through <a href="https://www.crowdrise.com/helpnepalearthquake/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">https://www.crowdrise.com/helpnepalearthquake/</a>
Friends of Nepal, Los Angeles is a 501(c) (3) California non-profit Corporation. We are happy to provide information to verify our status and corporate non-profit structure upon request

From a Facebook ex PCV/Nepal site: ""I'm an RPCV Nepal/168. I've also been serving on the U.S. based fundraising group Friends of Patan Hospital for almost 10 years. If you want a legit organization that's already on the ground administering to the injured check out:
All funds donated go directly to support Patan Hospital. We have this news in from colleague at Patan Hospital:

500+ injured, 46 casualties in our hospital, we are standby through night to have shift wise reste for staff, students..in pvt clincs, corridors, and basic science classroom, relateively safe being on ground floor, students have been great helping hands...will have more details by tomorrow,
the open space in front of hosp buildings and opd hall are used as makeshift wards. have postponed regular opd and or tomorrow, will need few days to get to normal hospital functioning""
Also some news article list good options.
I live in Seattle, WA, USA. I have donated to World Vision,

<a href="http://www.worldvision.org/news-stories-videos/nepal-earthquake" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">http://www.worldvision.org/news-stories-videos/nepal-earthquake</a> They actually had people on the ground prior to the quake. They have a lot of experience dealing with disasters throughout the world. They are also a locally based world wide charity, based in the Seattle area. I and many others highly recommend them.
Thanks, Tom. I'll pass that on thru other sources to people who have asked how to help.....Roger
as some of you may know,New Zealand has long had a presence in Nepal through Edmound Hillary (the first to climb Mt Everest along with his Sherpa friend Tinzing.
He then continued to return and help with building schools and hospitals.
He has since passed ,but it is no wonder he was considered almost a Saint in Nepal--(Perhaps its best he didnt live to see this )although his son ,Peter is there at present(and is apparently ok)

I remember treking in 1980 and thinking to myself how someone ''on the ground'' could distribute money where it was most needed (watching barefoot kids collecting water in the pre dawn icy conditions up in the mountains.
Ill look into one of the NZ charities you mentioned--thanx again

Since this thread is receiving prominence, Australians should note that the "ususal suspects" already have feet on the ground in Nepal, and have specific earthquake appeals in place. Donations are tax deductible.
also the australian nepali community have organised clothing donation collections as pasted below
FREE Courier Service for Donated Clothes by Airlines

As confirmed by Four Airlines, we can send donated cloths Free of costs to the Earthquake Disaster Victims in Nepal. If you have any unused cloths which is in good condition and worth to courier it, please send me your address. I will organise to collect clothes from your place. Alternatively, you can drop it at Suite 8 Level 13, 329 Pitt Street, Sydney NSW 2000.
Or Namsate bazaar, 14 Queen Victoria St (Binod} - 0450954044
* western Sydney region (Seven Hills). Yub Kharel - 0430 907 128
* Guilford - Janaki Poudel - 22 Talbot Rd Guilford. -
